title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
America's biggest banks will learn the results of their latest stress tests from the US Federal Reserve this week, with a passing grade expected to be a catalyst for billions of dollars in stock buybacks and dividends.

The expectation that banks will return more money to shareholders is a sign of how much cash the US banking sector has amassed during the pandemic.

The likes of Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase have been bolstered by government stimulus and buoyant revenues from trading and dealmaking.

The Fed capped dividends and banned stock buybacks last year at the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic. The central bank loosened some of these restrictions at the start of 2021 but still limited the amount of money banks could return to shareholders.

“The big banks came into the pandemic looking overcapitalised and after more than a year of no stock buybacks they look even more overcapitalised,” said one analyst.

Meanwhile, Wall Street's powerhouses are facing a challenge from Europe's largest retail lender. Santander has set its sights on becoming a major force in European investment banking.

Five stories in the news

1. Global equity markets extend losses The FTSE World index of global shares, which lost 1.9 per cent on Friday, declined another 0.3 per cent today in response to the US central bank taking a hawkish stance on interest rates and inflation. Monday's moves followed the worst week for Wall Street's S&P 500 stock benchmark in almost four months.

2. Western powers reignite Beijing anger Last week's show of force by China in Taiwan's air defence identification zone was the largest number of planes ever dispatched by the People's Liberation Army into the area, said officials in the region. It followed communiqués from Nato and the G7 criticising Beijing's activities in the Taiwan Strait and its crackdown on Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement.

3. Richest Latin Americans should pay ‘much more' tax The IMF's top official for Latin America has urged governments to make the rich pay “much more” in tax, in an interview with the Financial Times, saying the world's most unequal region will not develop unless it addresses demands for a fairer economic system.

  • Populism and the pandemic have interrupted Latin America's commodity-linked prosperity, says Morgan Stanley Investment Management's chief global strategist Ruchir Sharma.

4. Clayton, Dubilier & Rice bids for UK supermarket group Shares in Britain's fourth-biggest supermarket Wm Morrison surged 30 per cent following an approach from US private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice. Morrisons rejected the offer over the weekend but CD & R is to push ahead with its pursuit of the grocer despite being rebuffed, people close to the transaction said.

5. Raisi wins Iran presidential election by landslide Raisi, a judiciary chief and conservative cleric, won Iran's presidential election in a landslide victory over the weekend that gives regime hardliners full control over branches of the state for the first time in almost a decade. Western powers vowed to forge ahead with efforts aimed at reviving the Iran nuclear deal.

  • The FT View: Raisi's landslide looks to be a Pyrrhic victory, gathering nothing like the popular support needed to guide Iran through one of its worst crises since the 1979 revolution.

Coronavirus digest

  • Japan will allow spectators up to 50 per cent of venue capacity at the Olympics, subject to a maximum of 10,000 people, as the government chooses to disregard its medical advisers.

  • The Delta variant that swept the UK is dominant in Portugal and has appeared in clusters across Germany, France and Spain, prompting European health officials to warn further action is needed to slow its spread. 

  • One of Cuba's vaccines has shown 62 per cent efficacy in late-stage trials, using just two out of the three recommended doses.

  • Vaccitech, the group behind Oxford/AstraZeneca's vaccine, believes it has a better chance of treating cancers than new medicines based on mRNA.

Follow our live coronavirus blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter.

The day ahead

Activision faces showdown on chief executive pay Video games maker Activision Blizzard faces a contentious vote over its chief executive's $155m pay package after delaying the showdown in what critics said was an effort to avoid an embarrassing rebuke.

Ethiopia's first ‘free' poll Today's vote will be prime minister and Nobel Peace Prize winner Abiy Ahmed's first electoral test since sweeping to power on the back of protests in 2018 promising reform.

How should privacy considerations be addressed given data's emerging status as a tradable commodity? Senior industry leaders will share their insights at an FT virtual webinar starting on Wednesday. Register for free here.

What else we're reading

The new antitrust chief taking on Big Tech Lina Khan, the new head of the Federal Trade Commission, was our Person in the News over the weekend. James Politi, Washington bureau chief, wrote a well reported profile of the academic, whose appointment has sent shockwaves through Washington, Wall Street and Silicon Valley. The FT's editorial board says Khan's appointment is an important opportunity to equip antitrust policy properly for the Big Tech era. 

Capital for the people — an idea whose time has come While nobody these days has much sympathy for wealthy individuals or companies or really believes in trickle-down economics, the threat of tax and regulatory arbitrage by other states is real. California is applying some typically creative thinking to this problem, writes Rana Foroohar.

Behind the scenes at China TV The international expansion of CGTN has played a big role in China's soft power push that began in earnest with the Beijing Olympics in 2008. For Beijing, the channel is part of a geopolitical battle for the hearts and minds of the world. Will China become the centre of the world economy? This new video explores the idea.

Incentives abound to lure staff back to the office Management editor Andrew Hill delves into the perks offered by companies to lure staff back into the office. He reports on the latest data that show a gap has opened up between what employers hope for as lockdowns ease and what employees want.

Masters in Finance The FT's 2021 ranking of the world's best masters in finance programmes have been published. HEC Paris again leads the rankings, which are dominated by French business schools. You can read the full list here and learn more about the methodology used to calculate the rankings here.

Life & Arts

Summer books of 2021 The FT today launches its annual summer review of the best books of the year, starting with the genres of science fiction and business. You can share your favourite reads of the year so far here. The best responses will be published on FT.com as part of the wider series.

Correction: In Friday's FirstFT we wrote that pressure is growing on Randall Kennedy to retire as a Supreme Court judge when in fact we meant to say Stephen Breyer. We apologise for the error.
